title: 106_s148
content: The Act is titled the "Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act". Congress finds that approximately 500 bird species in the United States migrate among countries, with many neotropical migratory bird populations in decline, jeopardizing their long-term survival in the wild. These birds provide valuable environmental, economic, recreational, and aesthetic benefits to the United States and the Western Hemisphere. Neotropical migratory bird populations are declining due to habitat loss and degradation, posing a threat to their long-term survival in the wild. Conservation efforts require the commitment of all countries along their migration routes. The decline in neotropical migratory bird populations is primarily due to habitat loss and degradation, including pollution and contamination. Conservation efforts for these birds require the commitment of all countries along their migration routes and can be strengthened by increased coordination. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of neotropical migratory birds, support conservation initiatives in the United States and Latin America, provide financial resources, and foster international cooperation. The Act defines the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account and outlines conservation measures including population protection, habitat management, research, and law enforcement. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act focuses on protecting and managing bird populations, habitat, research, law enforcement, and community outreach. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act focuses on protecting and managing bird populations, habitat, research, law enforcement, and community outreach. SEC. 5. FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary will establish a program to provide financial assistance for projects promoting the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. Project proposals can be submitted by various entities including individuals, corporations, government agencies, and foreign entities. Entities eligible for financial assistance under this Act include officers, employees, and entities subject to US or foreign jurisdiction, as well as international organizations. To apply for funding, applicants must submit a project proposal. To be considered for financial assistance under this Act, applicants must submit a project proposal that includes the name of the project leader, project goals, qualifications of project staff, and estimated funds and time needed for completion, along with sources of matching funds. The project proposal must include the project leader's name, project goals, staff qualifications, estimated funds and time needed, sources of matching funds, conservation impact on neotropical migratory bird species, mechanisms for local public participation. The project must demonstrate conservation impact on neotropical migratory bird species in the US, Latin America, or the Caribbean. It should ensure local public participation, consult with wildlife authorities, respect cultural resources, and comply with laws. The project must consult with wildlife authorities, respect cultural resources, comply with laws, promote sustainable bird conservation programs, and provide necessary information for evaluation. The project must consult with wildlife authorities, respect cultural resources, and promote sustainable bird conservation programs. Recipients of assistance must submit periodic reports to the Secretary for evaluation. The Federal share of the project cost is required. The project must consult with wildlife authorities, respect cultural resources, and promote sustainable bird conservation programs. Recipients of assistance must submit periodic reports to the Secretary for evaluation. The Federal share of the project cost is required to be not greater than 25 percent, with the non-Federal share not derived from any Federal grant program. The non-Federal share for a project must not come from any Federal grant program. In the United States, it must be paid in cash, while in foreign countries, it can be paid in cash or in kind. The Secretary has specific duties outlined in Section 6. The Secretary, in carrying out the Act, shall develop guidelines for project proposals, encourage submissions from wildlife management authorities, select proposals that meet requirements and address conservation needs, and implement the Act accordingly. The Secretary will select proposals for financial assistance that meet requirements and address conservation needs, giving preference to those not covered by existing efforts and supported by wildlife management authorities. The Act will be generally implemented in line with its purposes. SEC. 7. COOPERATION. In carrying out the Act, the Secretary shall support and coordinate efforts to conserve neotropical migratory bird species by facilitating meetings, promoting information exchange, entering agreements with other agencies, and conducting appropriate activities. To support conservation efforts for neotropical migratory bird species, the Secretary may convene an advisory group consisting of individuals from various organizations. The group will assist in coordinating activities, entering agreements with other agencies, and conducting appropriate activities. The goal is to enhance conservation efforts for these bird species by collaborating with existing initiatives. The Secretary may convene an advisory group of individuals from public and private organizations involved in neotropical migratory bird conservation. The group will hold open meetings for public participation to allow interested persons to present statements. The advisory group for neotropical migratory bird conservation ensures public participation by holding open meetings where interested individuals can present statements. The Secretary provides timely notice of meetings and keeps minutes available to the public. The advisory group ensures public participation by holding open meetings where individuals can present statements. The Secretary provides timely notice of meetings and keeps minutes available to the public. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the advisory group. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2002, on the program's results and effectiveness under this Act, with recommendations for improvement and whether the program should continue. Additionally, there is a provision for the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account. Establishment of the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund of the Treasury to receive donations and appropriations for conservation purposes. The Secretary may use the funds in the Account without further appropriation. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account receives donations and appropriations for conservation purposes. The Secretary can use the funds in the Account without further appropriation. Amounts in the Account can be used for carrying out the Act, with a limit on administrative expenses. The Secretary can use donations and appropriations for conservation purposes without further appropriation. Up to 3 percent or $80,000 can be used for administrative expenses. Authorization of appropriations for the Account to carry out the Act is set at $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005, with at least 75 percent allocated for projects outside the United States.
